definition: Group of inherited **microcytic, hemolytic anemias** caused by decreased production of α- or β-globin chains, leading to imbalanced hemoglobin synthesis and RBC destruction.
why_it_matters: Common in Mediterranean, African, and Asian populations. Severe forms cause life-threatening anemia in infancy (requiring transfusions), while carriers have mild anemia often misdiagnosed as iron deficiency. Recognizing thalassemia prevents unnecessary iron therapy and enables genetic counseling to prevent hydrops fetalis.
how_youll_see_it: **Mild (trait)**: Asymptomatic or mild fatigue; low MCV, normal iron; often detected on routine CBC. Blood smear: **target cells** (bullseye RBCs) are common.

**Severe (β-thalassemia major)**: Infant (6–12 mo) with **severe anemia**, failure to thrive, pallor, **jaundice**, and hepatosplenomegaly as fetal hemoglobin wanes. Marrow expansion causes bone deformities (frontal bossing, "chipmunk" facies).

**Severe (α-thalassemia)**: **Hemoglobin H disease** (3 α gene deletions) causes moderate hemolytic anemia with splenomegaly but no bone changes. **Hydrops fetalis** (4 deletions) presents as fetal hydrops (fluid in multiple compartments, high-output cardiac failure) and is usually fatal if untreated.
problem_solving: Evaluate **microcytic anemia**: Check iron studies (low in iron deficiency; normal or high in thalassemia). Thalassemia is suspected if microcytosis is disproportionate to anemia, RBC count is normal/high, and RDW is normal.
Confirm with **hemoglobin electrophoresis**: β-thalassemia shows increased **HbA2** (and ↑HbF in major). α-thalassemia trait has normal electrophoresis – DNA analysis may be needed.
Family history and ethnicity are clues (e.g., Mediterranean or Asian ancestry). Counsel carriers on **prenatal testing** (CVS or amnio) to identify severe thalassemia in the fetus.

differentials.name: Iron deficiency anemia
differentials.hint: microcytic anemia with low ferritin and high TIBC; no family history

differentials.name: Anemia of chronic disease
differentials.hint: microcytic or normocytic; low iron but high ferritin (iron sequestered in inflammation)

differentials.name: Sideroblastic anemia/Lead poisoning
differentials.hint: microcytosis with high iron; basophilic stippling on smear

tricks: **Mentzer index** (MCV/RBC count): <13 suggests thalassemia, >13 suggests iron deficiency.
**Target cells** (codocytes) are classically seen in thalassemia (also in liver disease and post-splenectomy).
Trait carriers often have normal ferritin and mildly elevated RBC count despite anemia – don't give iron if iron stores are normal!
exam_appearance: 1-year-old of Greek descent with severe hemoglobin 6, massive spleen, bone marrow hyperplasia (crew-cut skull on X-ray) → **β-thalassemia major**.
Adult with mild microcytic anemia not improving with iron supplements; electrophoresis shows HbA2 5% (↑) → **β-thalassemia minor (trait)**.
Stillborn fetus with total body edema (ascites, skin edema) born to Southeast Asian parents who are thalassemia carriers → **Hb Bart's hydrops fetalis** (α-thalassemia major).
treatment: Mild forms (trait): No treatment needed; avoid unnecessary iron. Provide **folic acid** if any chronic hemolysis; genetic counseling for family planning.

Severe forms: Regular **packed RBC transfusions** (often every 3–4 weeks) to maintain Hb ~9–10 g/dL. Concurrent **iron chelation** (e.g., deferoxamine/deferasirox) to prevent iron overload (heart failure, liver cirrhosis, endocrine dysfunction).
**Splenectomy** may reduce transfusion needs in some (but increases infection risk; vaccinate and give prophylactic antibiotics).

Curative: **Hematopoietic stem cell transplant** in early life can cure β-thalassemia major. Gene therapy for β-thalassemia (e.g., betibeglogene autotemcel) has been approved. Prenatal options include preimplantation genetic testing to avoid an affected pregnancy.
red_flags: Infant with severe anemia (Hb <5) and high-output heart failure (tachycardia, cardiomegaly) → emergency transfusion (suspect β-thalassemia major).

Transfusion-dependent patient with arrhythmia or endocrinopathy (growth failure, diabetes, hypogonadism) → evaluate for **iron overload** (deposition in heart, pancreas, etc.) and intensify chelation.
Pregnancy between two thalassemia carriers (especially α-cis deletion) → 25% risk of hydrops fetalis; ensure prenatal diagnosis early.
algorithm: Normal or high iron, normal ferritin → consider thalassemia (especially if high RBC count, target cells on smear).
Do **hemoglobin electrophoresis**: ↑HbA2 (and ±↑HbF) confirms β-thalassemia trait or major; normal electrophoresis with strong suspicion → genetic test for α-thalassemia.
If thalassemia major confirmed → initiate regular transfusions + chelation; family counseling and consider curative transplant.

images.alt: Peripheral blood smear with target cells (codocytes) — red cells with a bullseye appearance, commonly seen in thalassemia.

cases.stem: A 22‑year‑old woman of Mediterranean descent is found to have a hemoglobin of 11.5 (slightly low) with MCV of 70 fL on a routine exam. She is asymptomatic.
cases.teaching: Microcytosis out of proportion to mild anemia with normal iron studies suggests thalassemia trait. Elevated HbA2 on electrophoresis confirms beta-thalassemia minor. No treatment is needed, but important to identify to avoid misdiagnosis and counsel on offspring risk.

cases.stem: An 8-month-old infant of Italian ancestry presents with pallor, feeding difficulty, and hepatosplenomegaly.
clues: Developed severe anemia after 6 months of age
Both parents carry a beta-globin mutation
cases.teaching: Beta-thalassemia major manifests in late infancy as fetal hemoglobin wanes, leading to severe anemia. Bone marrow expansion causes bony changes (hair-on-end skull). Management requires lifelong transfusions and chelation; stem cell transplant can be curative.
